Activity: Morning coffee and catch up on overnight emails. Check project status on the IT dashboard.

Work on the 'Data Sources' section based on feedback from @his-1 and @his-2 from email. Incorporate their input on data definitions and potential biases. Include information on the EHR system and data extraction process.

Focus on the 'Statistical Analysis' subsection. Detail the specific statistical tests to be used, including their rationale and limitations. Consider consulting @clinlead-1 (Clinical Lead) for input on relevant clinical interpretations.
Research predictive modeling techniques for influenza forecasting. Look into ARIMA models, machine learning algorithms, and other approaches. Evaluate their suitability for the available data.
Lunch time. Maybe a quick game of foosball in the break room with @da-1. I'm always up for a challenge.

Design and develop the first draft of the data visualizations. Start with a line chart showing the overall influenza case count over time. Use a data visualization tool like Tableau or Python's Matplotlib.
Create a bar chart comparing influenza case counts across different age groups or demographic categories. Pay attention to color schemes and labeling for clarity.
Develop a map showing the geographic distribution of influenza cases. Use color-coding or shading to represent different levels of infection.

Review the data visualizations with @qatest-1 and @qatest-2 (Quality Assurance Testers) to ensure accuracy and clarity. Incorporate their feedback on design and usability. Email @PEOPLE Request for Data Visualization feedback.
